40931142.review:
I like this game, but, as many others have stated, you will HAVE to turn the difficulty down on the bots unless you are VERY familiar with similar fighting games and are able to exactly press (NEVER spam) controller buttons, or play very well with a keyboard (for some reason I can press the buttons on the controller (wired XBox 360) and get a 50/50 response after a couple hits (unless you are VERY careful about exactly when you press the buttons, it seems to act as if there's a delay of about 100ms after most button presses, which can *easily* wreck your combos if you spam) but this issue is not present with keyboard, from my brief combo testing). 

The art aesthetic is the main draw (for me, anyways), and the combat system allows for skill and growth to most definitely be major factors. However, unless you can fairly capably beat Normal difficulty or better, you really should stay away from online fights; you will be destroyed. A lot. This game has definitely drawn its number of skilled players, and it makes most fights against them very one-sided. This wouldn't be much of a problem, except that they reward winners with salt, while losers get nothing, and you need salt to get cosmetic items from the salt mines, which you *also* can't even enter without salt. At least *most* of the players are sportsmanlike, but the ones that you come closest to beating (who also lose to everyone else) will more than likely spam-taunt you and abuse your/your character's weaknesses to the point of rage.

Furthermore, I seem to be finding glitches that crash my game or make me spazz out pretty bad online (no crashes, glitches, or jerkiness offline, from my experience), which, combined with my lack of proper experience with 2D combo-based fighters such as this, inclines me to avoid online in its entirety for the time being. The single-player currently just consists of Training and Arcade at the moment, and they're adding a Story Mode, which I will be very glad for, as well as at least one more character, so, while I recommend this game to both fighter fans and fans of the artstyle, I think I'll be only occassionally playing this game until the Story Mode is in (Arcade gets fairly stale after about 10-20 times, and being beaten to a pulp too fast to even see where to improve or getting tilted doesn't strike my fancy, either). 

Of course, if you have friends that will also play this game with you, that definitely would change the whole online experience, so be sure to take that into account, as well. 

TL;DR: It's a great game, but most average players will have to start off slow and really hone their skills to get the most out of this game before they add Story Mode, unless they have friends who enjoy both fighters and Lauren Faust's artstyle.

40908195.review:
Short review of Them's Fightin' Herds after the first hour I did some training and arcade mode.

This is an indie fighting game, powered by Skullgirl's engine. The original name of the project was My Little Pony: Fighting Is Magic. An fan made game based on [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/My_Little_Pony:_Friendship_Is_Magic]My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic[/url]. They sadly had to stop the project, renamed it and change the characters, that's why the game was delayed. So, what we can find after those changes? A good fighting game, powered by the most interesting and latest 2D fighting game engine created by Lab 0 for Skullgirls.

The main system of the game is close to Blazblue. 3 attacks levels (light, medium, strong attacks) and a 4th button for chara spec abilities. I don't remember abilities since I don't play enough, but the cow can throw a losso, the unicorn can charge the super bar, ect...

Wait, did I speak about cow and unicorn in  a fighting game? Yes, they change My Little Pony's characters for 4 feet animals. That sounds logical indeed, but there is the originality of the game. Your hitbox is very different of others games, and you have to keep it in mind for your spacing.

The only bad things are the soft feels unfinished yet, but it's an early access so this can change in future patches. Some animations are missing, sound can be delayed sometimes, and small things like this. Stages are not bad, but motionless/lifeless. Not a lot of characters for now, 6 playables chars and a boss wich is 4 animals (a bear, a snake, etc...) to beat with only one life bar.

But because all of this can be fix in the near future, and because this is a cheap game, I highly recommend to go for it.

40890410.review:
Early Access: It definitely has a lot going for it!!

This game is absolutely amazing! It's not even complete yet and it proves to be living up to its potential. The combo mechanic reminds me and feels kind of similar to the new Killer Instinct, making for near endless combos and super link-ups! Some may argue that the bots in arcade mode are extremely unbalanced. However, it provides a huge challenge for both skilled players and beginners!

This game only offers two game modes at this point of development: Singleplayer Arcade Mode (with Story Mode being added in the future) and Multiplayer, with the common Online Versus & Introducing: The newly unique Pixel Lobby Mode!. 

In the Pixel lobby Mode, u can hang around and chat / battle with random players around the world and with friends alike. You can also dress up the in-game avatar with various items obtained thru chests... Hope to see this mode expand a bit more to where u can roam the lobby with friends/players to find extra gear to customize your avatar! This has lots of potential living within this unique mode! 

In the future I hope to see more playable characters, maybe around 25 total. Perhaps the DEV's can also build a steam workshop support so people could make their own custom characters! Overall this game is a magnificent work of art, and cant wait to see the finished product of Them's Fightin' Herds~!!!! 

Overall Rating:8.0/10

(I Will Give An Updated Review When The Finished Product Releases & Hopefully Give It The 10/10 Allstar Rating!)

40833091.review:
Currently quite divided on this one. On one side, the game looks great, runs great on just about any rig and has some pretty great characters.
The actual combat however.. it's not bad, but it needs some *serious* polishing. Some attacks, most notably heavy attacks have hitboxes larger than their animations, Tianhuo's slide attack hits the target the moment the animation of it begins *even if you're out of range* and then there's the special move system, which works by pressing a combination of keys in a certain sequence, this however often either does not work, or performs a special move when you wanted to do a normal attack, something that happened a lot to me when I wanted to perform a dash and immedeatly attack afterwards.

Another issue are the combo's, in many an occasion once you get knocked up, or knock your opponent up and start hitting them with combo's, the target can just as well leave the computer, quietly make themselves some tea and come back without their character's control actually returning.
Sure, the game's not pricey, at 15 bucks, but if I pay for it I'd very much like to actually be able to play the game, and I did not pay to see my character being flung through the air and I'm sure neither did my opponents.

Besides all that there really isn't anything that makes this game stand out amongst other fighting games of its kind, other than that the characters are all 4 legged animals.

In its current state I rate it a 6/10, I hope the developers will polish up their gameplay before the full release so I can improve this rating.

40780110.review:
Been super hyped for this game for quite a bit and I wasn't disappointed. One of my friends purchased the game for me since I honestly wasn't expecting the $15 price tag, but I can see why. 

The music is probably one of the best parts of the game. The music is dynamic and changes according to the winning character. Each character's theme combines with each other to create a different soundtrack, like Arizona and Pom, or Olenader and Paprika.

Second is the art style. The art style is all thanks to Lauren Faust, ironically enough the one who designed the characters for My Little Pony: Friendship is Magic and other Cartoon Network favorites like Powerpuff Girls and Foster's Home For Imaginary Friends.

Fighting mechanics and animations are also great. Since I haven't played fighting games since 2009, it's pretty difficult for me to master all the combos and attacks, but once you understand them, it's really satisfying as you witness the animations that go along with all those kicks and shoves.

Overall, I'm pleased with the game. Good job, Mane 6. I guess being C&D by Hasbro turned out pretty well.

40769315.review:
Пускай я и полный нуб в файтингах, но в своё время поддержал кровными этот проект. Конечно, без увлечения одним небезызвестным мультсериалом тут не обошлось, но игра хороша не только из-за этого. 
Что мы имеем? Харизматичные персонажи от небезызвестной Лорен Фауст, отличная анимация, удобное и понятное управление, характерное для "западной школы" файтингов и требующее лишь знания приёмов и отточенных рефлексов (заведите себе контроллер, не мучайте клавиатуру). Ещё в игре просто фантастическая музыка: во время боя она меняется в зависимости от того, какой боец берёт верх, причём изменяется ("ремиксуется") сама музыка арены, а не просто подставляется тема героя, что-что, композиторами была проделана отличная работа — подобного я ещё не встречал ни в одной игре. Пиксельное лобби — неплохая находка для онлайн игры, это своего рода мини-игра и чат, где в любой момент можно вызвать собеседника на поединок, а потом собрать соль (валюту) и пойти бить хищников в обширном подземелье. Да и в одиночной игре ИИ компьютерных соперников не даст вам заскучать.
На данном этапе, увы, пока нет режима истории, но на то это и ранний доступ. В общем и целом игра заслуживает внимания.

40689071.review:
Despues de pasar por la tristeza de saber sobre el demasiado simple sistema de mashear botones de Dragonball Fighterz(excelente graficos y sistema, pero el gameplay no me gusta) y saber que el nuevo Blazblue Crosstag va a ser Scrub level, solo por que el 99% de los gringos les da pereza hacer 623 para hacer DPs segun Mori, estaba en una encrucijada, sera que no estoy listo para esta nueva generacion de Mashing Fighting Games? Pensaba en el retiro para volver a mi antigua vida de gamer de RPGs y shooters. Pero asi como cuando cae un haz de luz sobre ti que viene del mismisimo cielo , aparece este juego, una combinacion del sistema de combos de Skullgirls con los gimmicks en el boton D como Blazblue.
Un juegazo y esta en alpha, por asi decirlo.
GGPO: Los weebs siguen justificando a sus desarolladores japoneses de mierda que no usan rollback netcode, pero hasta ahora al igua que Skullgirls, la experiencia online de Them Fighting Herds es solida, permitiendome tener matches buenos con gente de EE.UU, (vivo en Costa Rica) y matches decentes con gente de Europa. GGPO for the win.
Pixel Lobbies: Son bonitos, son funcionales y tiene sus easter eggs.
Gameplay: Sistema de combos y de defensa de Skullgirls con una combinacion de gimmicks para cada persona en el boton D. No es un airdasher, por que hasta ahora solo POM tiene airdash, Paprika tiene Short hop, Tianhuo vuela (estilo Magneto en MVC2) y Oleander tiene teleport.
Dificultad: Entre facil y media, Oleander es por ahora el personaje mas facil de usar, es la tipica zoner con fireballs y minas, un especial de proyectil que cubre toda la pantalla, mientras Pom es dificil por que usa asistentes para atacar y tienes que colocar estos asistentes en la pantalla y utilizarlos a mano cuando los ocupes. En si, el juego en dificultad es parecido a Melty Blood donde simplemente apretas A B C y launcher para un combo. 
Ademas los devs hicieron algo inteligente, los antiaereos y los launchers se ejecutan de la misma manera en todos los personajes, permitiendote brincar de un personaje a otro facilmente, lo que si varia es el combo aereo, pero se resuelve con un poquito de practica. Los movimientos super especiales son iguales tambien en todos 236 AB.
Graficos: Los graficos son bonitos pero nada estilo Guilty Gear Revelator, no hay cambios de camara (Gracias a Dios!!) los cuales hallo molestos. Son graficos 2D bonitos, pero no esperes nada excepcional ya que como dije esta en Alpha, ahora estan arreglando cosas relacionadas con el gameplay y el online.
Musica: El punto mas debil del juego, no es la gran cosa y no agrega mucho hype al match, espero propongan algo mejor mas adelante.
Super recomendado.

40675370.review:
As of writing, the game is unfinished with unfinished animations and missing features. 

Despite this, the gameplay is solid and the characters are unique and entertaining to play. The music is top notch, and the dynamic music system builds even more hype in an already good fighting game. The training room already has all of the tool and information available for the combo hungry.

The characters are well-balanced, although some characters are always going to be easier or harder to master. The game is rather beginner friendly, and there are not yet any in game tools to teach people combos. No matter what, fighting games will always reward those who grind in the training room. Keep practicing.

The characters are well-designed (Thanks Lauren Faust) and the animations add to the personality of the characters.

$15 is a steal for a fighting game as entertaining as this. A lot of love was placed into this game.

edgy unicorn main btw

40664342.review:
Loving this game! The gameplay is fun and fast-paced, but not overwhelmingly so. All the characters are unique from each other while all still being relatively intuitive (except Pom). The uniqueness also means that some matchups can be quite different from each other, so there's a lot of variation in how you play. Also, the character designs are phenomenal, and the music is fantastic - the dynamic music is a subtle but awesome touch.

The only thing it's really lacking right now is content (lack of 1p modes, no ranked online, only 6 characters) but that's to be expected in early access, and all of that should be coming in the future. That plus some extra polishing to the animations would bump this game up from a great to a fantastic.

40649050.review:
I want to start off by saying that I am not a brony and I really dont care for the idea of playing as an animal like a llama or a cow or a deer. That just really doesnt appeal to me. However, as a fighting game player, I have been really enjoying this game and I certinally recommend it for those of you who disagree with the reasons I gave, or if you like fighting games, specifically skullgirls (you'll fit right in as it runs on the same engine.)

This is a satusfying fighting game that offers a lot to learn for fighting game fans, and plenty for more casual players even at its current early access state. That being said, the target mode is pretty useless and just some kind of speedrun mode. If that is what you're into, godbless, but I dont find any value in it. The training mode has a helpful combo trial mode that can teach you the basics of combos for each characters and what you should think about landing in a match. as far as online, there are basic lobbies, but the highlight of online is the pixle lobby. If you dont find yourself privvy with the fighting game crowd, you'll really enjoy walking around here and chatting with other players and discussing strats or going into the salt caves, a pretty entertaining mode that could use some more flushing out, but is still very interesting.

Currently this game is in early access. It is missing animations, sounds, and has some balance issues. However, it is very much a playable and enjoyable game. Even now, i can recommend this game for nearly anybody. That being said, you may not get the most enjoyment out of the game if you are unwilling to learn even a bit of fighting game basics. Plenty of fun ways to play with friends, but expect killers online and ready yourself.

This is a fun, enjoyable game that if even if the subject matter and history this game bothers you, if you can swallow your pride and give this game a fair chance, I think there is plenty to enjoy. Give it a chance before you judge it.

40630924.review:
My Little Pony: Fighting is Magic – вот, как назывался проект несколько лет назад, когда, к всеобщему удивлению, взлетела популярность сериала My Little Pony: Friendship Is Magic, который завоевал почётное место не только у мелкой аудитории, но и у куда более старших представителей человеческой расы (если верить статистике того периода, то люди, возрастом 16-45 лет были основной аудиторией сериала, да и что греха таить, таково положение и осталось). Fighting is Magic был одним из тех хороших примеров, показывающих, как нужно делать игры. Mane6 создали динамичный файтинг, в котором все способности каждого главперсонажа сериала использовали с толком, давая игрокам по-настоящему почувствовать, что он играет за героиню из My Little Pony.
Увы, популярность Fighting is Magic оказалась так высока, что жадные и завистливые Hasbro моментально встряхнули [strike]пиписьками[/strike] авторскими правами и потребовали немедленного закрытия проекта, грозясь завалить разработчиков исками. К счастью, нытьё Hasbro не одобрила Лорен Фауст, та самая женщина, которая и сделала шедеврами первые два сезона сериала про поней (дальше она отошла от дел, потому Hasbro начало вытворять всё, что ей хотелось, дабы срубить баблишка на столь популярной франшизе). Лорен решила оказать небольшую поддержку разработчикам и предоставила им новых персонажей для игры. Результат вы видите здесь – Them’s Fightin’ Herds.
Анимация персонажей узнаётся, так как перед нами всё тот же Fighting is Magic, но уже с другими героинями, которых не прибрала к рукам Hasbro, и с обновлённой боевой системой, которую, после выхода в стим, разработчики продолжают дорабатывать. Помимо того, в игре есть полноценное пиксельное лобби, где можно подурачиться с другими игроками и заняться переодеванием своего персонажа. Так же здесь поддерживается адекватная игра по сети, что обеспечивает полноценное веселье, как и подобает хорошему файтингу, а этим, позвольте заметить, на ранней стадии мало какой проект может похвастать. Динамичная боевая система, свойственная японским файтингам, и хорошая рисовка делают своё дело: каждый бой просто взрывается палитрой цветов и вспышек от многочисленных приёмов и жёстких комбо-атак. Кстати, зрелищности добавляет и здешний графон, над которым заметно постарались, пусть и бросается в глаза разница между теми объектами, которые были нарисованны, и теми, что делались в 3D. В придачу ко всему разработчики планируют ввести Режим истории, который раскроет детали сюжета игры... ну хотя бы для таких, как я, кому сюжет в файтингах действительно интересен.

В итоге, хочется поблагодарить группу Mane6 за их труды, и саму Лорен Фауст, оказавшую им поддержку, без которой мы бы навряд ли увидели эту игру. Напоследок скажу, что игра себя явно оправдывает, и я чepтoвcки рад, что разработчики смогут получить достойную награду за свою работу. И это при том, что ранний проект: Fighting is Magic – планировался как бесплатная фан-игра по известной серии, а в итоге он перерос в неменее качественный самостоятельный проект.
Забавно, что свинское отношение Hasbro сыграло против них. Взяли бы они разработчиков игры к себе, довели бы игру до совершенства и продавали, получая нехилый процент за счёт популярности My Little Pony и прекрасной работы группы Mane6… ну, получили бы, не поведи себя эта контора, как стая пи#ар@сов. Так тебе и надо, cpaнaя Hasbro, ты жирное паскудное ё$а№ое х&*ло, бл+%ь, ё$ твою мать, х&егрызное ты убогое зажравшееся жирдяйское уё%#ще.

40619165.review:
[h1]83/100[/h1]

I fnd this game [i]very[/i] hard to recommend and it just narrowly gets a recommendation from me.
Based on the skullgirls engine the game runs fluid and looks mostly fine, although it can be a bit jarring seeing static characters in the background of fights but I assume they will be animated in the future and honestly it is a fighting game so we are mostly focused on the main event, which is the fighting itself as opposed to some fancy backgrounds but it is jarring when you first notice it.

Which is as good a way as any to start and end this review, a lot of things look good until you notice something weird or jarring, for example every character has a magic meter of some sorts which is not the super meter as you may expect but a seperate meter similar to v-trigger in streetfighter 5 or the auxillary meters in vanguard princess. 
This seperate meter is important to different characters in different ways and for some it is mandatory that you fill it in order to maximize damage/combos but others can seemingly ignore it altogether.
At this point I would liken this game more to vanguard princess and have to call it an "anime fighter" as the focus is on big flashy combos and not on fighting fundamentals, so if you were expecting a footsies game or a projectile war then you are wrong as this is more akin to he who hits first, (and doesn't drop the combo) wins.

Unlike skullgirls which featured a combo-breaker system, I could not find one here which was a mixed blessing as I either completely styled on opponents, securing a 35 win streak in the process or I get completely stomped with little to no middle room. Skullgirls had a very similar problem however the ability to break combos at least gave you something to do when you were getting beaten unlike here where you may as well put the controller down and grab a drink.

Compounding this issue is weird controller lag/input detection that means you have to input combos immediately without hit confirming first or else they will immediately fail, which is problematic because it means blindly hoping your attack landed. This wasn't an isolated issue either, I have come across quite a few people complaining about this and I know this is not a ggpo specific problem because skullgirls uses ggpo and it manages just fine online for even the most terrible of connections.

Infact in the case of skullgirls, it is much more likely your opponent will be teleporting around the screen and the match will disconnect due to being unplayable than your hits and combos will fail. I don't buy the argument that the game is in early access and so these issues will be fixed simply because it has been 4 years of games in early access (on steam) and you just roll the dice and hope the game gets fixed/patched/[b]finished[/b] but this is one instance where I would hope to be wrong and the final product does come through polished.

Hope however is the first step on the road to disappointment and although I have rated the game highly I did mention that it just ekes out a recommendation and that is because we are innundated with fighting games right now so the competition is stiff. If you are a casual you will probably get a few hours playtime that honestly hardly warrant buying the game and if you are a hardcore fighting game player, well, you are being spread very thinly right now!

The game comes at a very bad time and honestly this was the best time it could possibly come out regardless since even more fighting games are on the horizon so they cannot delay release forever can they.
Back to talking about the game however and it boasts dynamic music although honestly I did not notice it but what I did notice was that the music would frequently cutout, unless dead silence is a part of the music, so there is that. Dynamic music is as old as Phantasy Star Online and that was over 20 years ago, come on guys, sort it out.

The graphics, well look at the game, it is a cartoon come to life but then again so was skullgirls and dragonball fighterz so there is little praise I can heap on this game that it sadly is not outshone by from its direct competiton and that is a huge, huge shame because this game feels like it is coming from a place of love.

With all that said, you can see the game has issues of which the biggest is the flow of fighting and while you may or may not have liked skullgirls there is no denying that the playerbase for skullgirls was small and if this game follows suit then consider if you want yet another almost dead fighting game on your hands. At this time of this review I found one lobby with 20 people in it and a whole bunch with 1, 2 or 0 and 0 was the norm!

40613311.review:
Это нейтральный отзыв

Ждал игру довольно долго (4 года), поддержал деньгами на кикстартере.
С одной стороны очень красивый дизайн как фона, так и персонажей, и местами оригинальные комбинации.
С другой геймплей просто выбешивающий, боты разносят вас как котенка, странная тренировка, которая спустя 6 несложных комбинаций из трех ударов заставляет выполнять комбинации земля-воздух-низ-земля-усиленный удар в одно дыхание с микроскопическим окном для ударов. Если вспомнить игру Skullgirls, такая адовая сложность была только в самых последних тренировках.
Не доработаны лобби игры. Зачем то требуют денег за вход в пещеру или за открытие сундука с украшением. Местная валюта зарабатывается только за победу над противником-человеком. Мы случаем не в Баттлфронт 2 превращаемся?

Я может пойму что команда пытается еще сбалансировать игру, но из-за этого они не уследили ни за тренировкой, ни за лобби. 40607689.review:
This was the game that made me finally take the plunge, get a stick, sit down and learn fighting games.
There isn't much more I can say, being a newcomer to the genre itself, but I will try.

It's- wonderful. The style, the animations, the music- every day I spend 30 minutes in the Combo Trials mode and steadily get a little better every day. When I started out, I couldn't [i]touch[/i] Velvet, my first opponent in Arcade Mode, about two weeks ago.
Now - I just beat Arcade Mode today, and there was a great deal less button mashing and more actual comboing than in any other fighting game I've ever bumbled my way through. I will keep on playing, increasing the difficulty settings bit by bit. That in itself speaks to how hooked I've become.

[i]Of course[/i], it is an Early Access product. There were some crashes after launch, some menus could use an itty little bit of work, the story mode and matchmaking are still to come, and, most tellingly, characters' animations aren't finished yet.
Honestly, however? The game is in a pretty good state already. The only jarring part are the animations, especially in the battle intros and outros. Once they tighten that up - we'll have a truly great thing in our hooves.

40602731.review:
I feel like I've played this game countless times before, like a weird mix of Vampire Savior with Marvel/Skullgirls thrown in, maybe with some BlazBlue on the side. Just doesn't feel very unique or distinguished to me. Defensive options in this feel very lacking to me, limited reversal options, the footises (hoovsies?) and spacing in this game just feels all kinds of strange due to every character being on all fours and how normals are executed. It's just a strange feeling, and you get so easily pulled in by highs/lows. Even with Push Blocking, it's too easy to get locked down with hardly any way out, heaven forbid you get knocked down once, then you're really screwed In other words it's like pretty much any other "anime" fighter out there, it's largely a setplay "single player" based game and these types of games don't really hold my interest for long, especially when the fighting game market is FLOODED with games like these as it is. I mean you look at the #1 fighting game on the market right now, DragonBall FighterZ, I think that game is absolute nonsense in terms of gameplay.  Defensive play just isn't great, so you need to always take the initivative to overwhelm your opponents with relentless rushdown, because if you get caught blocking, you aren't winning, you're losing. Sadly the fighting game community these days prefers fighting games where literally every move has to hit confirm into a long drawn out combo and you aren't well equipped with any real good reversal options, especially without some kind of resource. The combo's in this game are super easy to do and figure out, but it just feels like there isn't a whole lot of variety because you can turn just about any hit into the same bnb combo. I play mostly old school SNK fighting games and combo's in those tend to be alot shorter, far more damaging, and usually with more restriction in what you can do, because those games tend to be more about slugging it out with your opponent rather than confirming every light low or overhead into a full combo. I much prefer games where there is a large emphasis on feeling the opponent out and exchanging individual beefy hits.

Basically I feel like, this game has some of the same problems I have with Yatagarasu, it's a game I feel like I've played numerous times before and does alot of the same things other big hit fighting games do, but feels way more limited in that regard. However unlike Yatagarasu, this game actually has a very nice art and audio direction, much more convient menu's and UI, and it actually has legit licensed GGPO netplay, something Yatagarasu promised years ago, and still has yet to deliver. Also unlike Skullgirls, I apperciate the fact this game is a strictly 1v1 fighter, I could never get huge into Skullgirls because they wanted to push tag teams+assists so hard for that game, and it's that same reason I could not get into DragonBall FighterZ. I tend to dislike team based games that involve tons of random garbage goin on screen, and DBFZ makes it even worse because of how homogenized most of the cast is.

All that aside though, this being an early access title and all, I think this game has alot more potential if they just beef up/adjust the movesets on the characters, maybe add EX versions of Specials, and I think the damage should be increased, make those individual hits count more, make combo's scale less, especially supers. I get fighting games these days are all about converting every teeny tiny itsy bitsy hit, whether it's a low or overhead into long combo's, but you don't have to make every move work like that. Back in my day we had beefy strong ass normals, they weren't cancelable, they generally combo'ed into nothing, but they were their to establish spacing, pressure the opponent, and when they hit, they hurt quite a bit on their own. Games that used to do this quite a bit like The King Of Fighters for example, no longer does this anymore really.

Old man rambling side, if you liked Skullgirls but preferred it as 1v1 game, this game would probably be right up your alley. Naturally if you liked the gameplay in games such as Vampire Savior or maybe some Marvel titles or even anime fighters like BlazBlue, you'd probably find something to like here. These types of games have never been the kind I am in love with or anything, but I can apperciate the hardwork that went into making this and hope it can grow/develop enough to get some kind of scene of it's own, but then at the same time I feel this game will have the same problems games like Arcana Heart and Melty Blood have, appealing to the most niche of niche fighting game playerbase.

tl;dr, it's a cute game, great presentation, super easy to pick up and play, but I feel like the gameplay isn't very unique/distinguished, but I understand it's still a major WIP, just like Skullgirls was for the longest time, so hopefully it manages to evolve over time into something much more.

40575411.review:
I'm rusty when it comes to writing reviews, as I've primarily reviewed episodes of ongoing series in the past. I do think a review of this game is in order, however, so I shall oblige.

Mechanics

Truthfully, I'm not sure where to begin. The games uses a chain-combo (light attack -> medium attack -> heavy attack -> launcher attack) and launcher system to continue combos in the air and directly cancel attacks and special attacks into super attacks. Everything about it feels fair, fluid, and easy to use, yet difficult to truly master when in practice. Controls are responsive, the sounds of attacks hitting is fitting, and damage is handled fairly (in my opinion). As a fighting game enthusiast (not master), it is my opinion that the games feels fantastic to play on the sheer weight of its mechanics and their implementation alone.

Art

Art is in the eye of the beholder. As of the time of this review's writing, the game isn't fully complete, so certain things aren't fully implemented or animated. That being said, the backgrounds are visually appealing and characters stand out enough that they don't get lost amongst the bright colors of said backgrounds. The character designs are interesting, animate well, and consistent with the chosen art style (i. e. they do not clash visually - there is no stark difference in overall aesthetic). Attacks look like what they are supposed to be (the ones that are finished, that is), and also stand out from the background. This reviewer is of the opinion that the art is well-implemented.

Sound

The voice-acting is pleasant to listen to, doesn't sound forced, and is fitting for each of the characters, bolstering personality rather than clashing with it. The sounds themselves are often basic, but they are perfectly fitting and convey exactly what they need to convey to match character, weight of attack, and overall aesthetic. Sound is well-implemented, just as the art is.

Netcode

For a fighting game with online multiplayer, netcode is of the utmost importance. As of yet, even when playing against players marked as being on the opposite coastline, this reviewer has experienced no lag during any matches. That is not to say there will be none, just to say that this reviewer has not encountered any and is thus of the opinion that the game runs beautifully in online modes.

The high quality of product in regard to the game's price (at the time of this review( was such a surprise that this reviewer can only wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys fighting games. Players new to the genre may want to get started with a different title before jumping into this game, but, if they like the way fighting games play, this is a must buy.

40562774.review:
This is not normally how I'd start a review, but given the game's astetic, art style, and nature/vibes it gives off, want to make a disclaimer (feel free to find it humerous, I'm just throwing this out there)

I am NOT a brony or into MLP, however, I have nothing against brony's or people into MLP. To each their own, the reason I wanted to bring this up is due to the game's art style and theme being VERY MLP esque. I however am judging the game on it's own merits as a game. Although one thing I will mention is I wouldn't be suprised if some form of a collaboration between this game and MLP came into light/fruition. Also bear in mind that due to this game being in the very BEGGINING stages of early access, bear in mind I will still critiuqe it, but will give the game the benefit of the doubt/give the game some creedence


Anyway, let's get to the reveiw

Them's Fightin Herds is a 2D Street Fighter esque style game with the fast pace of SF IV to be precise, whilst having a very cartoony and not taken serious at all feel to it. However these are just the first few things that come to mind and the first impressions I had with the game.

Let's get to what I enjoy about the game as well as it's problems

Positives:

Diverse characters and likable designs, concepts, and ideas-I enjoy the concept of an animal fighting game, and it's nice to know that aside from just looks and voices, each character plays differently. They each have their own unique movesets and you quickly learn what playstyle or type of character they are after you fight them  or try them out. Your best bet is to try the first stage with each character and see which one fits you best

Music and Stages-Each stage has a very distinctive vibe to it reminiscent of the character you  are fighting with it's corresponding looks and music, Arizona is in a countryside, Oleander is a night time/slightly ominous looking swamp/forrest, the lama is around a type of field/farm looking area (if I remember correctly) etc

Flow, Controls, and Gameplay-Controls feel very nice and the pace and some elements of the game's controls eminds me of Skullgirls (oddly enough Lab Zero is mentioned as one of the collaborators) and whilst this point is regarding controls and not design, the design can also be thought of as an indicator that the game also has a very skullgirls feel to it, almost as if SF and Skullgirls had a baby, The flow of the game feels smooth and as mentioned befoe, one of the first impressions is SF IV. That element in particular is with the complexities of combos themesleves yet the ease of picking up the controller, learning/looking at the controls, and learning the combos. in short, like SF IV, the combos and combat itself is easy to understand and learn, difficult to master


Bonus Points (these are positives that are not major, but are cool brownie points, and tbh, one of them got me somewhat excited)

Voice acting and dialogue-The dialogue is cute, expected, but in a funny cheesy way and it compliments the game's atmosphere and vibes and imo adds charm to it. Not to mention, if my hunch is correct and my ears don't decive me, I think Arizona is voiced by Tara Strong and I think that brown french animal in that snowy area (don't remember all the names instantly after only playing for 43 minutes) is voiced by Grey Griffen (Vicky from FOP/Catwoman from Batman) of if that's inccorect, my other guess is Audrey's voice actor from Huniepop!



Negatives-(Again, I will reiterate that I know this is early access so I can give the game the benefit of the doubt, and these are small negatives that should be taken note of, but they do NOT break or "damage" the game in major ways

Roster SIZE-I understand the whole "quality over quantity" thing with games or entertainment in general. But with fighting games imo, you need a balance of quality and quantity when it comes to the roster and character types/playstyles, not that they aren't diverse, it just needs expanding, which will most likely be added via an update or patches (here's hoping, but that seems extremely likely)

No tutorial-Whilst training is available. Bear in mind that CHARACTER SPECIFIC tutorials or a basic controls tutorial is absent, sometimes the best learners need physical experience and not just visual via looking at the controls and buttons, again, this can be forgiven for the time being given this is in early access.

No AI fights-Again, it plans to be added, it's just a bummer it isn't available

Balancing-This is one of those games where even easy presents some bit of a challenge, which, for most games, isn't a problem, however with a fighting game that's a special case where, (at least in my opinion) is a sign of needing balancing/fixing, so hopefully this gets fixed in the future

Overall-Them's Fightin' Herds is a cute, funny, fun, and suprisingly deep indie fighter with plenty of potential and challenge, and here's hoping that over time the game expands upon itself and grows with more content, characters, and capabilites, because imo it has potential to be up there with skullgirls or brawlhalla in terms of popularity and notoriety if done right

40521008.review:
So I've played the game for a few days now, I can say it need ALOT of work.

For start, the sync of the characters talking at the begining, its like lipsync thats way off. I feel like its a japanese english dub style as they speak, or... The mouths don't move at all...
Each character has a yin and yang style. One can DESTROY another where another will just whipe the floor with you.
Pom is OP as hell for the fact that you can't really get combos on her. She falls to the ground before you can even start them and can open you up anytime with very quick attacks.
I know many will say shit like, "Get better and learn the game"
As incomplete as this is, I feel like I have to learn the exploits vs play the game to have any fun.

I've played some online battles, lost them all... It's not fun to play other players as many already know how to break every single combo, open you up to do a insane amount of damage and, well, unless you play against a noob that has NO clue how this game works, you are going to loose, loose and oh yeah, loose every single match.
Even with countless hours of training and learing your character, they will still exploit the block, and drop to break your combo just to open you up for a insane combo that... well is just really not fair in the slightest...

As a early access game, it is totaly a early access title, needs alot of work and a little more balance with the characters.
I do recommend it but be in for a bumpy ride until its polished and tuned to balance things out.

40511734.review:
This just goes out to all fighting games in general, since I don't play a lot of fighting games and when I do play them I get the same feeling, and this game is no acception.

I just find that if you're new to fighting games then there's really no point to trying to get into it. You can train all you want and try to become familiar with it, know the combos and what not, but there'll always be someone better than you, and when you find that player there's no chance for you to do anything. They'll combo you to death and there'll be no chance to do anything at all. You can try and block but they'll find a way around it. On average my games last up to 30 - 50 seconds because I failed to block one attack which leads to me losing two thirds of my health from that, which at that point what is the point?

As for the games I do win it just feels really unsatisfying. Half the time I've no idea what I'm doing and when I do know what I'm doing it's the same combo over and over again. There's no reason to win or lose really.

Overall if you're new to fighting don't start with this one. In fact don't get into it at all. It'll either make you mad in the long run or feel unsatisfying.

40499753.review:
I have never really been a fighting game fan. 
Only ever tried Marvel vs Capcom, Mortal Combat N64 and an old version of Street Fighter.

This game as brought fighting games into a new light for me!
I can't recommend this game enough. Really great art direction and amazing net code!
Inputs are fast and concise. Long combos are challenging but rewarding.
My favorite thing about Them's Fightin' Herds is the absolutely breath taking music.
Every stage has a base song that is played. Depending on the characters used during the fight new instruments are added that match the feel of the character being used! It's truely amazing. I wish more games had dynamic music like this.

The only flaws that I can bring against the game:
Small but refined roster.
Dialouge synching problems.
Place holder animations.
The boss of the arcade mode is bland and a step down in difficulty than the normal characters you face.

All these problems can easily be chalked up to it being in Early Access and are most likely going to be fixed by the game's full release.

40497846.review:
This is a good game. I didn't like it, but it's good.

It's a historycal child of "Fighting is magic" game, which was a fanmade MLP (My Little Pony) themed project. Since fans had  lots of problems with Hasbro owning the franchise, they decided to ask for Loren Faust's help and make their own fighting with lots of references and their own magic. If you play this game you see that they succeseeded in that task. There is actually much more than original game could give you.

Pros: 
+ Amazing artstyle by Loren Faust herself
+ Great music
+ All of a sudden it's a freaking multiplayer thing! Amazing!
+ Animation and sound quality levels are high
+ Even though it's an realy access game it has almost everything you wanna see in fighting
+ Very user-friendly (because you gotta share, you gotta care) pixel lobby with lots of servers with actual non-toxic people on them and fun little things and clothes with descriptions

Cons:
- My personal problem was in controls: I can't play with joystick and keyboard controls are stiff and uneasy, even less easy is to adjust them, simply because there is no "Disable second player" option.
- Game has her ancestor's problem in menu - it's not easy to choose a color palette when there is no strict and straightforward explanation what options you have and you end up scrolling those colors forever. I am just being dumb here, this is really a super minor con that affects just me probably.
- As it is made by mane6 and it's a MLP-based (in the past) game, there are only 6 characters and I doubt there will be many more
- AI will kick your bottom. It's horryfying in it's OP-ness.

It's really good, yet unfinished and doesn't suit me, sadly. I had to refund this game. I will probably buy it when it comes out of Early Access state, but not now.

You might like it tho, so see for yourself.

40485181.review:
So let's get the elephant out of the room first: yes, the game's artstyle is heavilly inspired by a certain children's show. That is going to deter a lot of people.

But going past that, the game is extremly good. Actually, it is way more competent than it has any right to be. And in honsetly, the artstyle is one of it's strongest points as well. It's flexible, colorful and most importantly, fun, a nice diversion from the regular fighting games. 

As was intended, players of Skullgirls will immediately recognize the fast paced, combo heavy playstyle that requires a fair ammount of training. It is responsive, not cluttered and while you can get away with mashing to some degree, at the very least more than SG, as some abilities are cheeky and do questionably reasonable ammounts of damage, it is on the whole fair and balanced.

It is unlikely to become my main game, with Street Fighter V and DBFZ dominating the market right now, but it will be a nice one to play when I don't want to be as competetive as playing those (though I will likely still try to compete hard here).

In summary, leave your reservations elsewhere and try this game. For the ammount it's asking it's way too good to pas up for both hardcore fighting game fans and those who want to start out.

40478364.review:
As of this review, I've put about 27 hours into the game, and will try to give a decent piece, maybe update later on. I'm gonna be going from topic to topic just as it pops into my head, so don't expect any major coherence from paragraph to paragraph.

To start out, I've been following and anticipating this game for a good while, so I'm definitely at least a little biased. At that, though, I don't have much of a metric for fighting games other than Soul Calibur and Tekken, and it's been years since I've played those, not to mention they're 3d. I've put about 18 hours into casual skullgirls play over the last couple months, but haven't really been soaking in anything about the game, just kinda coasting along and hitting buttons. So that's all to say, my frame of reference here is almost nonexistent for the genre.


The roster is interesting, with a lot of fun color palettes, and the music is fantastic. The UI felt like it was fighting with me at first, but I've adapted to it pretty well, and it's not even an inconvenience past the first hour or two maybe, in my experience. This current build is sparse on anything other than core content, which is to say the fighting itself. I think a lot of people will argue that story-content is as or more important to a release, but in this case I'd have to highly disagree. It'll be out when it's out, and as far as an experience goes, I've already gotten more than an hour per dollar out of this game without feeling like I was missing anything.

The controls are straightforward, and simple combos are incredibly, stupidly easy to pull off. Simple LMH>Launch>Aerial LMH stuff will get you through your first steps, and I was able to decimate many of my fellow beginners with this combo and slight variations for about the first fifteen hours or so it was out. The training mode offers combo trials, which will teach you everything from basic combos like the one I listed, to master-level, 20+ input chains. It's certainly a system that requires and rewards patience, as any newcomer to the 2d fighting genre is going to have a hard time memorizing inputs to the point where you can read and execute them like reading words on a page. In the several hours I've been attempting combo trials, I've made it down to the end of the intermediates, and feel like my muscle memory is kicking in to the point where I could probably reach the same point on a different character in slightly or significantly less time. 

The netcode is very solid, although not without some stutter here and there. It never breaks the pace significantly, and I wouldn't be surprised if it was exclusively on my end anyway, so I won't take away points when I'm still able to have very capable matches with people who have 200 ping or more, with only minor latency.

The Pixel Lobby is a fantastic addition, and I'm glad it was able to make it into the EA release. Being able to speak with people in-lobby has mostly been a good experience, although your mileage will obviously vary. There's a lot of cool customization on your avatar (Although I wish we had palette swaps on the pixel characters), and you have the opportunity to garner much more through the Salt Mines, a kind of dungeon-experience filled with NPC monsters that are liable to make you cry your first few goes. The rest of the lobby is a very good experience. Matching up is easy, spectating is easy, although once you're locked into a match, you'll be forced to spectate until the end, and you can even still enter training while in the lobby, marked as your character pummeling a dummy to other players.

Inputs are seemingly difficult, but in retrospect very fair. I've been missing inputs since release, but looking into training, and being more conscious of what I'm doing has led me to realize I just need practice. And practice has absolutely tightened up my inputs and responses, as I feel I'm missing significantly fewer after just a few hours of repitition on the difficult ones. Which isn't to say any inputs are particularly difficult in any objective measure, but newcomers are sure to whiff on Velvet and Paprika's DP inputs as often as not, in the beginning, and even just executing supers can seem very precise when you're not aware of your openings after and between attacks. More than once I'd find myself trying to execute a super far too soon, only to realize when examining frame data in training that I was simply too early, or even that I was just straight dropping my inputs.

None of this is to say that the gameplay and controls are perfect, because I don't know. I just feel that in my experience so far, anything that's felt "wrong" has been fixed with a little bit of effort and reflection. I'm also sure it feels different than some or many other fighting games, but that's not exactly a valid con either.

Each character seems to play very different, and of the three or so I've semi-consistently attempted (Oleander, Velvet, Tianhuo), I'm finding myself having to adjust my entire perspective on gameplay just to make dents in more skilled players. It's honestly very rewarding. I definitely do not undervalue the worth of losing either, whether it's to the AI, or better players, because after four a four match losing streak, I'll often find myself changing my approaches and sometimes I'll even come back from the depths for a tie, or close, and that always teaches me something that I can take into future matches.

I've briefly hopped into Arcade mode and the Target Break thing, and don't care much for either. I feel you'll either enjoy them or not, and I personally definitely prefer spending my time facing off against other players, and training. I feel that I'll enjoy Story Mode much more, though I can't know for sure at this point.

As far as negatives go, the only one I've really noticed is a lack of some animations, and character frames. I sincerely don't know what else to call a negative, especially gameplay-wise, because nothing has felt like one so far. I'm reading the negative reviews here on Steam, and finding I can't sympathize with many of them at all. I've seen the AI referred to as cheap and broken, which is about the most understandable complaint, but even then, I haven't had much trouble with them after some practice, so I don't know if it's just a skill thing, or if they're actually cheap compared to other 2d fighters.


Yeah, Idunno, as far as a first fighting game goes, I'm into it. It feels good to play, it looks great, the music and general sound-design is ace, and it's had a very welcoming community.  I can see myself sinking a fair amount of time into this between work and other hobbies. Maybe not the fifteen hours a day I managed on release, but a couple hours of practice, a couple hours of matches, every other day, every two days, yeah, that sounds like a genuinely good time. Looking forward to watching the game grow.

Will update if anything else comes to mind, or maybe once I reach a more significant number of hours/once 1.0 is out.

No story mode whatsoever, no tutorial, unfinished animations, annoying lipsync, awful UI, absolutely horrendous AI, and pretty much everything else pointed by other people in the negative reviews. 40474215.review:
TLDR: A cute exterior with well-polished mechanics complex enough to be engaging, but not so overwhelming as to be unwelcoming to new fighter players.

Pros:
+ Built on Lab Zero's engine (Same as Skullgirls)
+ Very well done aesthetic and art direction
+ Normals feel very snappy and satisfying
+ Not too focused on infinite or super-long combos (see: skullgirls)
+ Each character has a distinct playstyle and character feel
+ Pixel Lobby has a PvE environment to grind out cosmetics for Pixel Lobby (TF2 fans, go nuts)
+ Various QoL things, like context menus for pixel lobby on chat with controller, or keyboard chat
+ The soundtrack is surprisingly good
+ Each character has a well-established personality, and this combined with the aforementioned playstyles make each character stand out and feel unique

Cons:
- AI (as of this review) is overtuned, and the gaps between difficulties are staggering
- Art is currently unfinished with certain vfx (e.g. Oleander's Magic Teleport) being rendered in animatics
- Online matchmaking is limited to lobbies (as of this review)
- No story mode as of yet
- Extra cosmetics (i.e. Skullgirls, Blazblue, et al.) only are obtained if you have the "full" game (second encore for skullgirls, rev 2 for xrd, etc) [this is in the fine print but just in case people get confused]
- No tutorial (however, there is training mode, and there are combo lists within training that you can practice)

Overall, the game is very well done for an Early Access title, and I feel like the state of the game can only improve over time. If you are just starting out at fighters, maybe wait until the AI gets fixed, or persuade a few friends to help you learn, but this is a very enjoyable experience for those who are even remotely interested in fighters, while also having enough detail and potential to be mastered by veterans.





(p.s. Paprika is best ' ͜ > ' )

40470193.review:
Now I know what you're probably thinking (unless you're not the kind of person who takes things at face-value). Yes, this is a pony-based fighting game. We get it. Y'all think it's trash just cuz the characters have very distinct similarities to that one very familiar pony show that everyone seems to love to hate on. We get it. But if you're gonna just disregard this whole thing based solely on its surface-level design decisions, then you're gonna miss out on a hell of a good game.

If Skullgirls is an introduction to Street Fighter based games, this game is the Skullgirls of games like BlazBlue or Guilty Gear. Which is also kinda funny since this game is built with the Skullgirls engine, so you catfighting fenatics already know that the engine certainly works smoothly. And it's not just that part that works either! The controls are responsive, the gameplay is fun and easy to pick up, and the characters are very diverse and introduce players to different styles of fighting characters. (Except grapplers. Unless you count Arizona as a grappler, which...I don't, really.) I had never even considered picking up a zoner character until I played Oleander, and it's the most fun I've had with the archetype.

The game also comes with a Pixel Lobby, which basically functions as a way to find players to fight without having to directly seek them out and make a lobby with them, while still having a bit more interactivity than the Skullgirls Quick Match system. The game itself has about 8 official lobbies, with a whole bunch of fan-created lobbies to spice things up if those ones are full. When entering, you are given a little avatar you can customize with hatsand accessories. Bored of the hats you're given? Go to the Salt Mines! There you can fight Predators and open chests to get salt which can be used to open more expensive chests to get the aforementioned Hats and Accessories.

Cons? Well, it's hardly finished, for one, though I wouldn't let that bother you too much. All that's really "missing" per se are things that wouldn't really affect gameplay otherwise, like missing animations and stuff. That's not counting things like Story Mode and quick matches, but you can get a lot of the content missing there through other means, like Arcade mode and the aforementioned Pixel Lobby.

In the end, I'd say the game has a lot of potential, and definitely is a lot of fun right now. I implore you to look past first impressions and give the game a try. You just might find a fighting game that you'll really enjoy. I hope this helps you in your purchasing decision.

40469629.review:
Been waiting for this game for years. Backed it during its campaign. Now it's finally here. Well in Early Access. 
I'm not really into fighting games. Never played much of any before this. Only backed it because the team went through a lot and plus it looked like a nice game. Now enough backstory, time for the positives and negatives.

+ Visuals. I love how the game looks. Not much to say about that.
+ Music. Man I love the soundtrack of the game. Plus the Dynamic Music System is incredible too. Makes fights much more intense. 
+ Gameplay. This game is fun as hell. Like I said, not a huge fighting game fan but I can't stop playing this. It's simple enough for a new player to understand but takes a lot of practice to master. I can understand why I got my butt kicked. Pulling off combos is so satisfying.
+ Characters. All the characters are unique and fun in their own way. Love em all. Everyone can find the one that fits their playstyle.   
+ Pixel Lobby. The Pixel Lobby is such a fun place to just fight other people, talk to them, spectate fights, earn cosmetics for your little pixel fighter, and has co-op against CPUs.
+ Community. The community is great. In game and on Discord server, everyone is cool and friendly. Makes the experience much better. Plus the devs are great too. Not really about the game but still felt like adding.
+ Training. The amount of options in the training mode should be enough to help you master combos and even make your own. Definitely helped me get better.

Now for the negatives.

I don't really have much to say. Only negative thing would be that the game is in Early Access. So it's missing a lot. 
- No Story Mode. -Some bugs. - Lip Syncing issues. - Some sound issues. - No ranked play. 
- Needs different pixel lobbies. - Some characters aren't fully complete in terms of visuals.             - No option for private lobbies. 

All of those issues can be fixed in a couple of months though so I'm not really worried. They don't really affect how much I'm enjoying this game. So if you want to spend 15 bucks( or 11.24 if you have Skullgirls until March 8th) and just wanna play a fun fighting game involving adorable animals then get it. If the issues I listed above are too much to handle then just wait until the game is actually complete. For now the game gets an 8/10 from me. Oleander is best.

40454127.review:
What you need to know:

Them's Fightin' Herds is a 2d fighting game with 6 characters with a My Little Pony history. Online is mostly played through lobbies. As with most fighting games, expect people to kick your ass. All fights are 1v1. The games that are most similar to this are Skullgirls and BlazBlue. There isn't much else besides the salt mine in the lobbies and waiting for story mode to come out. Expect to get your money's worth getting better online: that's where the longevity of fighting games always occur. It's as good of time as any to start now before people start learning more of the game's mechanics in the next few weeks.

Positives:
+Wonderful and buttery smooth MLP-inspired art.
+Crazy mechanics from every unique character keep every fight fresh and fun (especially with the magic system).
+Color palatte of characters taken from characters (there's an animal crossing skin for the alpaca, a spyro skin for the dragon, and a god damn deadpool skin for the cow)
+Probably one of the most unique and interactive lobbies you'll see in a fighting game (very similar to ArcSys games like Guilty Gear Rev2 and Dragonball FighterZ)
+Master your skills with combo trials via training mode. How convenient!
+THE SALT MINES
+An in-depth fighting system with a lot to learn!
+$15. Pretty cheap for a game like this, and discounted if you own Skullgirls or Guilty Gear Xrd Revelator/Rev2.

Negatives:
-Lack of a tutorial for new players.
-Steep learning curve for new players.
-Not much besides salt mines and the upcoming story mode to keep new players interested.
-Early Access = a few main game stuff is missing (specifically certain character animations, quick match, story mode and tutorial mode). The game will become a regular release in a few months, so they're close to finishing the game.
-An in-depth fighting system with A LOT to learn...

FAQ:

How is this related to My Little Pony/Why are there so many Bronies playing?
Originally the game was created to be My Little Pony: Fighting is Magic. Hasbro put on the ol Cease and Desist on the game, and further development was canceled. The team agreed to recreate the game using all new characters based on the main 6 of the show (thus the devs were called Mane6). MikeZ offered the Skullgirls engine to the team, and Lauren Fraust, creator of MLP:FIM, created the designs for each of the characters. After 4 or so years of development, the game is finally out on Steam.

Where is the content? I thought there was 4 years of development.
If you're unfamiliar with fighting game development, it's a pain. Especially if you're an independent studio. There is an incredible amount of variables that go into creating a fighting game because of it's complexities. Say you have 6 buttons of attack like in Skullgirls. You also have to consider how each button is pressed when crouching, in the air, and how they chain into each other. Not to mention programming special moves, designing hitboxes and hurtboxes, and worst of all, balancing the game so that no insane-looking character is better than the other insane-looking character. If you're still not convinced, just know that development for this game is focused on the long-term. That means that simply having a bunch of single player modes will not help the game when eventually, everyone else will play each other online. For the developers, online comes first.

What the hell are the Salt Mines?
The Salt Mines are a semi-hidden trial in the online lobbies. Simply pay some salt that you gained off of playing against other players, and you may fight the AI in a sort of rogue-lite setting and collect cosmetics for your character. It's pretty fun, and quite possibly even co-op.

What character should I pick? Is one character better than the other?
Don't fall into this trap. Ever. Pick a character that you want to play and stick with it. If you want to play a character just because it's on a higher tier, then you'll get less fun out of the game. Worry about tiers only if you're attending or watching a tournament.

Why should I worry if I'm a new player?
Simply put, this game does not have a tutorial to teach you. And trust me, there's a lot to learn. Don't know how to block? How to pull off special moves/commands? Don't know about any of the new mechanics? Then you'll be completely lost if you go in blind. If you want to play this game as it's intended, you'll need to do some prior research, or better yet ask for help! Anyone in the lobbies or the Steam forums will gladly help you.

Where do I start if I'm a new player?
Learn the fighting game basics. Try to get a feel for your character. Learn normal button presses, learn to block low 75% of the time, and if you lose, HIT THE REMATCH BUTTON. Vets love it when they see a new player keep trying. Here's a video that might help you. https://youtu.be/nd9sEB6ku14

En 2011 este equipo creo un FanMade de un juego de peleas de la Serie My Little Pony, con el tiempo y unos $600.000 dolares que fueron otorgados por la gente en la pagina Indilogo, Mane6 puso en marcha Them's Fightin' Herds. Ya siendo 27 de Febrero de 2018 el juego rencien tiene 5 dias de su salida en Steam siendo un juego de Acceso anticipado, y vaya que se nota, pero no arruina la experiencia en ningun momento

Pros:
-Aun siendo 6 personajes todos se juegan de manera distinta, unos son mas de atacar a mele, otros a larga distancia y otros directamente prueban al jugador haciendo que juege como se le de la gana

-Nunca y lo digo de verdad vi unas configuraciones como las de este juego, que en graficos tengas la opcion de literalmente ELIMINAR el fondo para mejor FPS es algo que yo nunca lo eh visto antes
-Muchos modos de juego que estan por venir, incluyendo una campaña con historia
-Por ahora ningun DLC ni contenido cosmetico de pago (sacando los de BlazBlue o SkullGirls que los obtienes comprando esos juego, aunque no se si te los dan si ya los tienes de antes)

Contras:
-Se nota MUCHO el porque esta en EA o AA para mis amigos que no saben ingles. Ejemplo Oleander tiene algunas habilidades donde literalmente sale el modelado en lapiz del personaje, esto puesto porque todavia no han echo la animacion, pero es un detalle gracioso que me rei al verlo por 1 vez
-Al ser nuevo no hay muchos servidores, y mucho menos servidores cercanos a Sur America, por lo tanto el servidor con menos MS tiene 180 
-Poco contenido y es lo normal en un juego nuevo, pero al ser EA se espera mucho contenido proximo y ya confirmado por los creadores
-Dificultad de IA aplastante, que en Normal paresca que estas jugando contra Koreanos la 1ª vez que lo toques es un poco hdp
-Sin tutorial, el juego directamente no tiene tutorial, si quieres aprender algo lo haces tu en el modo practica, ahora llendo a algo mas tecnico lo tendras que aprender solo o por videos en yt o dentro del foro del juego

Es un EA como muchos, Poco contenido de salida pero habra que ver, tiene un gran futuro, que me deje mejor sabor de boca un juego de pelea con 6 personajes basado en un juego de My little pony que el nuevo de Dragon Ball ya dice mucho, asi que por mi este juego es mas que recomendable si de verdad quieres un juego de pelea y no la mierda de Dragon Ball Fighter Z

40437095.review:
[B]Them's Fightin' Herds[/b] is a surprisingly solid indie fighting game made by [b]Mane 6[/b] the same people that brought us the fantastic fangame known as "Fighting Is Magic" (look it up). TFH is essentially a reskinned, retooled, and deeply improved successor to the aforementioned fangame with GGPO netcode, animated lobbies, and easy to learn but hard to master gameplay, featuring adorable woodland creatures from something you'd expect out of [B]Rivals of Aether[/b]. It has fast and furious combo-oriented combat with a variety of characters suiting different playstyles. If you're looking for a comparison, it's somewhat similar to games such as Guilty Gear, Killer Instinct or Blazblue; whereas dropping a single combo can sometimes cost you an entire match. On the outside it's cute and adorable, but inside is something bloodthirsty and brutal.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1315112593
[h1]THE GOOD[/H1]
+ Adorable animated characters created by Lauren Faust.
+ Deep combo-oriented fighting mechanics.
+ Really neat animated explorable lobby rooms.
+ Seamless online netplay, quite populated as of writing.
+ Great soundtrack.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1315113548
[h1]THE BAD[/H1]
- Unfinished animations and textures. (WIP Materials)
- Audio desynch with animations.
- Repetitive and somewhat lifeless backgrounds.
- Twi- err [b]Oleander[/b] might need a nerf or two.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1315113317
[h1]THE UGLY[/H1]
Hearing annoying Twitch streamers earrape lobby rooms.
Thankfully you can mute them, but it's still annoying.

[H1]BOTTOM LINE[/H1]
It's good, really good. And it's cheap. If you enjoy complex
competitive fighting games, go ahead and give it a shot.
For an indie title, they really put a lot of love into it.

[b]Recommended 7/10[/b]

Thanks for reading! And if you enjoyed this review, give it a like!
And i'll see you next time!

Voy a seguir jugando este juego durante años...dejame contarte por que:

Segui el desarrollo practicamente desde 2011 cuando todavia era conocido como "My Little Pony: Fighting is Magic" y cuando en 2013 Mane6 recibio esa carta de Cese y Desista de los abogados de Hasbro murio una pequeña parte de mi :(

Hasta que anunciaron que el proyecto no estaba muerto, y de la mano de Lauren Faust (Creadora de MLP entre otras series) Them's Fightin' Herds* Iba a ser una realidad.

7 años despues por fin puedo jugar este genial juego en toda su gloria y no cambio casi nada. Los controles son casi perfectos, faciles de aprender, pero aun asi la diferencia entre un veterano y alguien que recien empieza es inmensa, y si, lo digo porque ya me dieron una buena paliza los jugadores de la beta...como los odio (?

Y la musica...ningun otro juego puede darte un surgimiento de adrenalina mas grande que cuando en medio de la pelea la musica se remixea segun quien va ganando. Es larga la explicacion pero por ejemplo, si sacas una ventaja grande con Arizona, la musica se convierte en country rock, si haces lo mismo con Tianhuo, la musica empíeza a incorporar Erhus y otros instrumentos orientales, etc.

En fin, aunque seas un veterano en los juegos de pelea o busques empezar en el genero, este juego es una opcion que deberias tener en cuenta (MUY EN CUENTA)

*Reto a cualquier hispanohablante que este leyendo esto a pronunciar correctamente el nombre.

40433101.review:
Amaizing game so far with exception of a few things that hinder the playability, and then some balance issues.
 Game doesn't seem to optimized for regular controlers simply due to the game overall being far to input sensitive, this wouldnt be a problem if Launching attacks which seems to be a fairly important attack in majority of characters move sets wasnt Crouching forward holding, This makes transitioning into the move increadibly impracticle unless you are playing stick,  (And no "Just Get a stick" is not a good responce), Having tested with both Stick(don't have one but used friends) , D-pad and c-stick, Stick plays really well still have issues with CSF sensitivity but the gates built into the stick make it managable and a requirement for pratical playing of this game, D-pad  with experience seems to not want to settle on either the crouch or forward and more often chosing a solid direction, and C-stick (sadly my preference) has it the worst as getting the Crouching forward input is a hypersensitive location and often time moving the stick just into position triggers the CSF attack making the attack the hardest piece of everycharacters to use.  An Easy fix is to change the launch move, input wise, to the crouching attack instead as it makes the controls and combo's more reliable AND intuitive across all control types without affecting any characters combos (except potentially Arizona)


Character Issues: 

Oleander: Lack of mobility outside of this characters teleport is her gimmick i guess, but it seems forced. Increasing her dash distance is the only thing that hinders the character overall, Raw Super (level 1) should do more damage, as it only does 7 more damage than something like Velvets CSB light.

Velvet: Characters damage in general is way to high, Her reward for spacing is far to great as everyhting she does gives her managable space from opponent. Moveset is Obsurdly safe on block, and needs to be toned down, all version of her CSB attacks do OBSURDE ammounts of damage and should de dialed down a tad bit. Ultimalty character excells to well at all locations of the screen with far to much safety. 

Arizona: Is in a great spot with exception of her entire moveset seemingly worthless against crouching opponents, This NEEDS fixed as there is really not reason her light and mediums CSF should completely wiff. otherwise i suggest you give her another lasso attack for close range (holding Toward opp. ) so her combos can be more flush with it as a utility tool and make it so she cant land more than 1-2 lasso hits per chain anyways.

POM: Havn't noticed to many changes needed, great hitbox sizes and fun character.

Paparika: THERE IS SUCH A THING AS TOO MUCH LOVE

TianHuo: Suffers from Crouching to launcher move being to sensitive, causing it to be far to liable to do the Airial grab which is ussless on grounded opponents (or you could be cool and give it a wiffing hit box since she is doing a fancy twirl) Super is only cappable of being landed as a combo ender, make her hieght gain when it launches from ground shorter so she can catch cheeky grounded opponents with it raw,(SINCE THE REST OF THE CAST CAN) and hit Box for it is FAR TOO SMALL.

PROS: 
-Game Feels increabily Nice
-plays well with exception of the Launching attack
- has much potential DLC character wise

Cons:
-Very sensitive controls, mean game needs to be as intuitive as possible, so the hiding of an important combo piece behind a a sensitivity trap works against feel of game

40432889.review:
7/10

The PVP is fair and addicting. It has a Pixel Lobby mode where i spend the most of my time with this which kind of makes it feel like an MMO. It has an interesting artstyle but some animations and textures are missing. For example in the start of a fight the characters stay freezed in 1 frame until the go. But it is Early Access so it is excusable.
The music is fine, the control is OK if you don't have fat fingers.

Overall a solid fighting game. If you are a fan of Skullgirls, Street fighter etc. you should definitly check it out. Just keep in mind that it is in Early Access so it only has 6 characters and things like Story mode and ranked Matches aren't out yet.

My only fear with this game is that the additional characters they are planning to implement in a DLC will have additional fees. Because playing with only 6 charakters will get boring in a while. Sure mastering all these characters can take a decade, but allready with 3 of these charakters i can't see myself having fun playing them.

40432143.review:
It is really hard for me, as a backer, to write this review.

You see, I understand it is Early Access, but I have also been playing this game ever since we got handed the first playable build.

Just to explain my fighter game experience, I have been playing them since the original Mortal Combat, these days mostly play Melty Blood, Blaz and Street Fighter 4. Casually, yes, but I do win every now and then.

Now, technical problems:
- It is impossible for me to change the game into fullscreen mode. While it is not a BIG deal breaker, it does kinda suck cause I can only see the upper half of the super meter cause of this.
- A major amount of animations are unfinished, again it is Early Access, but come on, you had 3 years to do this.
- Absolutely zero lipsinc. Intros and outros are very buggy.
- UI in this game is one of the worst I have seen in my life. I could not believe there can be a worse UI than the original Melty Blood but boy, was I wrong.
- No tutorial.
- AI basically has two modes: A) Barely even trying. B) Never missing a block and air juggling you for 50+ combos. The AI slider is a joke. A bad joke even.

Gameplay Issues: Disclaimer, since there is no tutorial in the game, I may be wrong about most of these, but you cannot exactly blame me for that. I tried.
- Seems like there is no Perfect Block/Perfect Dodge/Perfect Counter mechanic to get out of infinite combos. I swear I have to be missing something here cause if so, first attack is all that matters which is a really bad gameplay.
- Juggling harder than Blaz.
- A lot of attacks have really bad hitzones. I personally wanted to main Arizona but I have quickly learned that her lasso attack, which is the only way to replenish resources by the way, has probably the worst hitzone in the history of gaming. It is so pixel perfect that you have to literally be a quantum computer to be able to pull it off and if the enemy is laying down, in the air, moving, attacking or doing literally anything other than staying perfectly still, it will not connect. This is just one of many similar problems.
- General character balancing: Who thought its a good idea to give Totally-Not-Twilight extreme range on every attack, ranged attack that does not cost any resource, ability to constantly teleport and even teleport that does half of the screen of hitzone and is one of her most damaging attacks? Insane much?

Like seriously, I knew char balancing is gonna be kinda shoddy in the backer build but I was hoping this would have been solved by, you know, people playing the game and devs paying attention. Do they even play their own game?

- It is impossible to counter pick. Most melee characters get melted by ranged characters like Velvet or Arizona. Feels like this game was supposed to almost be like League of Legends or DOTA, where you counter pick chars, cause some chars are much better against other chars.
- Salt Mines are currently entirely pointless.

So yeah, there is a lot wrong with this game. I had MAJOR hope for it, not cause it was made by Mane6 and would have been a nice middle finger to Hasbro, but cause I wanted another good fighter in my life.

It is not often I feel strongly about me backing a game, but this time, I wish I could refund it.
